title: Help needed identifying naturalist/botanical font, maybe 18th century
content:
Hello,

I'm desperate to find out if there's a digitised version of this font. It's on a Cavillini Papers poster of butterflies. Apologies for the poor quality of the photo - I tried to find the poster on the Cavallini website but without luck.

I suspect it's not a font as such, as each letter looks individually handwritten, but wondered if there was a chance someone had done some kind of reproduction of it.

Many thanks.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [IMG\_1295.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20111225140031/http:/typophile.com/files/IMG_1295.jpg) | 523.27 KB |
| [IMG\_1293.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20111225140031/http:/typophile.com/files/IMG_1293.jpg) | 797.73 KB |
author: Christopher Miles

comments.content:
I think you're right - this looks hand-drawn to me.

- Lex

I agree about being hand-drawn, but I went looking to see if I could find anything that might work as a substitute. I thought [P22 Dyrynk](http://web.archive.org/web/20111225140031/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/ihof/p22-dyrynk/) has a similar quality of looking somewhat hand-drawn and yet professional.

- Mike Yanega

Matthew Carter's 1977 revival of Cochin might work:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20111225140031im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Cochinital_6376.gif)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20111225140031im_/http:/typophile.com/files/COCHIN2_6689.gif)
